text: Hi Vladimir, you mentioned several times that you use a DAG data structure. However the examples in your videos are all trees. Do you have any examples that benefit from the sub-tree sharing that characterizes DAGs?

text:
Hey <@UCUSW7WVD>!

The trees that are shown in the video were stored as a DAG with hashes as keys (just like in Git), if same tree node is used in several places, only one instance is stored. However, for now this reuse is not displayed in UI in any way.

Actually, I am not sure I understand about which benefits exactly you are talking. I have following thoughts in mind:

---

It is good to show that some subtree is used somewhere else. This way you can explore how this or that function is used in other places.

For example we have following DAG:

```place1:
  subtree1: {foobar: baz}
place2:
  subtree2: {foobar: baz}```
We can somehow display connection between `subtree1` and `subtree2` and navigate from one to the other.

However, if user decides to modify `place1/subtree1`, then editor should allow it for the sake of good user experience. It should feel like text and should not break things in other parts of the system by default. Thus, this connection between subtrees will be broken, because they are not equal anymore.

To have subtrees that are actually pointing to one thing and change simultaneously I plan to use explicit references to a subtree, for example:

```references-list-keyword:
  ref1: {foobar: baz}
place1:
  subtree1: {reference-keyword: ref1}
place2:
  subtree2: {reference-keyword: ref1}```
Tree editor should recognize this referencing and display references to the trees as actual trees (with some highlighting that would indicate referencing).

This referencing can be made nested, which would start to look like lexical scoping in many PLs.

text: It sounds like you're mostly using a DAG instead of a tree as a space-saving optimization. Am I understanding correctly?

elements.text: It sounds like you're mostly using a DAG instead of a tree as a space-saving optimization. Am I understanding correctly?

text:
For now DAG structure is not used for anything except storage saving, yes. Differences from simple trees may show up on the level above, in PL.

For example you have two different functions that expect trees with two different interfaces:
```func1(Value):
  {title: S} = Value
  do_something(S)

func2(Value):
  {asString: S} = Value
  do_something(S)```
Because we work with dags we can create a value that satisfies both interfaces with single value:
```asString: "a string value"
title: "a string value"```
Or, because it is a DAG, we can display it like that:
```asString:
   title: "a string value"```
Two keys, but one value.

That kind of thing will be really useful only on PL level, which I haven't reached yet.

text:
I didn't really. I asked about benefits because you mentioned the power of a DAG several times in the video.

The space savings don't seem very important. And since you don't use it yet in any externally visible way, I wonder if the complications this will cause in the UX are worth side-stepping for now.

The sense I'm getting is that you chose a content-addressable representation for trees that naturally ended up supporting DAGs. I might consider undoing that decision just to avoid having to jump through hoops to ensure that edits in one place don't affect other places. Just create a new id for every node, and never reuse nodes. Periodically garbage-collect if you need to, to save space. But really, disk is cheap.

Very interesting project! What are you building it in?

text:
> what happens if shared content is equal (as in identical content/hash), but doesn’t really represent the same thing
I have a terrible thing in mind: I don't want to provide content addressability. Thus, this problem of equal hashes but not equal content is a problem inside single storage and can be resolved by some additional checks.

I want to deny content addressability because I want to work with trees that are not necessarily stored as DAG. As I mentioned in video, trees may represent file system or a database. Providing correct hash for a table that constantly changes might be a problem.

Have you considered turning multiple values for the same key into a collection? And if you did, what made you decide against it?

text:
> Have you thought about how that distinction can surface in the user interface?
I don't have a ready sketch for that. What I know is that visually it will be very different, pretty much two different modes of editing.

Right now I am thinking to add a side window for editing data from reference.

> Have you considered turning multiple values for the same key into a collection? And if you did, what made you decide against it?
I wanted to use simplest possible data structure, from which everything else can be constructured.

I can express this:
```key1: value1
key1: value2
key1: value3```
As this:
```key1:
  0: value1
  1: value2
  3: value3```
Allowing several values for same key may make UI for pattern matching much more complicated. It also adds ambiguity -- what if several values do fit the pattern?

text: I’d be really interested to learn more about the API. Would it be possible to specify a protocol in line with <https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/> but where the AST is in focus and not the text file? More than just the editor I guess it would be possible to do better search, autocomplete and version control if the dependencies from each expression is known or even more fine grained incremental compilation. One important compromise I suppose you must have put some thought into is the requirements you put on the language in terms of order vs chaos to put it in your words.

text: Good artists copy; great artists steal. :smile:  I think it might be hard to design an API that all languages can implement. Immutable variables might make it easier to compute up and downstream dependencies and if the order of the declarations doesn’t matter you could perhaps order them alphabetically or something like that. LSP is pretty nice in that you can choose what part of the API you support.
